title: TADA Bosses Indicted for Illegal Cab Services
text:
Top management at ride-hailing app TADA, who have lost a war of attrition with the established taxi lobby, will appear in court after being indicted for operating illegal cab services.

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office said Monday that it indicted Park Jae-wook, the head of VCNC which operates TADA, and Lee Jae-woong, the CEO of parent company Socar.

The two executives have been charged with offering illegal cab services using vans driven by chauffeurs.

TADA was launched in October last year with a fleet of 300 Kia Carnival 11-seater vans and drivers who are hailed with smartphone apps. The service was a roaring success because it avoided many of the frustrations of conventional taxis, but the taxi lobby fought back viciously and got the government on side.

Taxi drivers in Seoul filed a complaint against TADA in February of this year. Everything now depends on how a judge chooses to interpret exceptions in the relevant law, which has not caught up with changing business models and makes it illegal for individuals without taxi licenses to transport passengers for money.

An exception allows vans with 11 to 15 seats to be rented for chauffeured services, and this is what TADA took advantage of.

But the conventional taxi industry claims that TADA is exploiting a loophole and is no different to illegal chauffeur services using private passenger cars, and prosecutors share that view.
description: TADA Bosses Indicted for Illegal Cab Services
